p.span: This setup is for marketing companies selling and producing customized corporate gifts, like mugs and t-shirts. A typical sale order is a company buying 50 red t-shirts for his employees, customized with their logo on the pocket, with quantities like: 5 Small, 10 Medium, 25 Large, 10 XL.

template.p: In addition, the company runs a B2C eCommerce, for individual buyers to buy products online. Clothes are defined with multiple variants, like size and color.
To customize products, they use 3 techniques:

ol.li: serigrahy; printing on t-shirts, using a frame (the main one on t-shirt)
embroidery (more costly, so usually for shirts, or hats)
printing the logo and sticking the printed paper (mugs)

Visit the B2C Shop: show variants and
select other colors on t-shirt (photos change)
Show the B2B Form: from top menu, you can "Request a Quote"

template.p: This customized form will create an opportunity in the CRM, with the right information, and the optional logo of the client.
From the CRM, schedule a meeting. As you meet the client, you can create a quotation and use the product catalog to add swag like keyrings & mugs.

Create a purchase order from B&C, with the product "B&C Inspire Women". As this product is often purchased and sell in batches, a matrix of quantities per color and sizes opens, allowing to place an order for:
Validate the reception for all quantities at once. You cals show the product catalog, another approach that could be useful if you want to check the stock on hand as you purchase.
template.h2: Flow 3: Sell 20 Customized T-shirts, with pocket logo
template.p: To create a quotation, select the template "Pocket Serigraphy". That will insert the two mandatory services:

ol.li: Setup cost: creating a frame for the printing (Qty: 1)

p.span: Then add the product "B&C Inspire Woman", a grid open to select multiple quantities per size. Print the quotation to see how it looks.

template.blockquote: Note: the template also adds "Custom Keyrings" as an option to the offer, to upsell the client. If the customer orders the keyring, it's configuration is to purchase them automatially to manufacturer SwagPro. (make to order)
template.p: As the customer confirms the sale order, two tasks will be created:

ol.li: Build the serigraphy frame based on customer logo

template.p: First, you need the receive the logo from the customer. From the project "Logo Design":

ol.li: Designers move the task to the stage "Request Logo"

ul.li: That sends an email automatially to the client to request the logo

ol.li: When the client replies to the email with his logo: the logo is automatically attached to the task
Once received, the designer checks the quality of the file, and move to "Frame Creation, then "Done"
Once the frame is Done, The Serigraphy Task is automatically moved to "Frame Received" + Green (Studio automated Action)

template.blockquote: Note: all logos appear in the Document Management System, under the Project > Logo Design workspace. You might tag the final version of each document, if you want ot use document management.

blockquote.font: In this setup, we chose a very simple approach, based on tasks, rather than manufacturing orders. Workers just see the tasks to do in a project. That simplifies the workflow.

template.p: Serigraphy workers work in the project "Serigraphy"; a task has been created to follow the printing job. As they start customizing the t-shirts, they move the task to "In Printing", and then "Done" when it's finished.
Quantities to customize are available from the linked Sales Order.
Now that the t-shirts are customized, you can deliver the 20 products from the inventory application. Use the barcode scanner, or the backend, up to you.
